terms.definition: A genus of fungi (yeasts) naturally found on human skin. In Seborrheic Dermatitis, these yeasts proliferate excessively by feeding on sebum and producing irritating substances.
A protective 'slimy' layer produced by microorganisms (like Malassezia) to protect themselves from antifungal treatments and the immune system.
Fundamental components of fats and oils. Specific fatty acids (chain length C11-C24) feed Malassezia and must be avoided.
The outer layer of the skin that retains moisture and protects against external agents. In SD, the barrier is often compromised, causing inflammation.
Chemical compounds formed by the reaction between a fatty acid and an alcohol. Many 'heavy' esters (e.g., Isopropyl Palmitate) are food for Malassezia.
A chemical process where water breaks molecular bonds. Malassezia uses enzymes (lipases) to hydrolyze sebum triglycerides and release irritating free fatty acids.
General term for fats, oils, and waxes. Not all lipids are harmful to SD: squalane and MCT oil are 'safe' lipids.
International Nomenclature of Cosmetic Ingredients. It is the standardized list of ingredients found on the back of cosmetic products.
Oily substance produced by the sebaceous glands of the skin. It is the natural food for Malassezia.
Medium Chain Triglycerides (C8 and C10). A special oil that Malassezia CANNOT metabolize, making it the only safe oil to moisturize skin with SD.
A stable hydrocarbon derived (often) from olives or sugarcane. It is chemically identical to part of human sebum but does not feed the fungus.
Measure of acidity. Healthy scalp has pH 5.5. A higher pH (>6.0) promotes Malassezia growth.
Enzymes produced by Malassezia to 'digest' fats (sebum or cosmetic products) and transform them into nourishment.
Accelerated detachment of dead skin cells, visible as 'dandruff'. It is an inflammatory response to the presence of irritating free fatty acids.
Common emulsifiers (e.g., Polysorbate-20, -80) that contain fatty acids. Often used in medications, but can feed Malassezia if not balanced.
Ingredients derived from microbial fermentation (e.g., Galactomyces). Very popular in K-Beauty, but risky for SD because they often contain nutrient residues for yeasts.
